description: AncientMetagenomeDir is a community-driven repository curated by the SPAAM Community, offering comprehensive lists of published ancient metagenome samples. By aggregating references, metadata, and related resources from diverse studies around the world, it provides an essential central point for researchers working on archaeo- and palaeo-genomic projects. This repository helps streamline comparative analyses by hosting standardized information and regularly updating relevant data. Although it is a valuable resource for those interested in ancient metagenomics, it primarily serves as a static directory rather than an interactive software tool for active data processing.

Arches is a comprehensive, open-source software platform designed to support the needs of cultural heritage and research organizations by providing robust tools for creating, managing, and visualizing complex geospatial data. Inspired by the needs of heritage communities, it helps build and maintain resource inventories, fosters collaboration, and ensures data can be analyzed and shared. Arches also supports customizable workflows and advanced data modeling.

This curated Google Doc offers a wide range of archaeological and anthropological data sources, including publicly available databases, archives, and specialized collections. Aimed at PhD students who must adapt or modify their research projects in response to COVID-19, it provides practical guidance on accessing, analyzing, and interpreting these valuable resources from various regions and time periods. With an emphasis on flexible, remote-friendly work, it allows researchers to continue despite travel limitations or temporary lab closures.

ADMUR is an R package designed to model underlying population dynamics using chronological datasets, particularly radiocarbon data, through a variety of frameworks such as Continuous Piecewise Linear (CPL) modeling. Using BIC-based model comparison, it can calibrate 14C samples and generate Summed Probability Distributions (SPD). CPL modeling can estimate the most likely population trajectory from input data, and SPD simulation analysis helps measure model fit. The package thereby offers robust tools to explore and compare demographic trends in archaeological or paleoenvironmental contexts.

description: The 'Classical and ancient Linked Open Data' resource is a curated repository that brings together a broad range of open, online data sets focusing on classics and ancient history. This collection serves as a centralized reference for researchers, historians, archaeologists, and enthusiasts, offering direct links to publicly available datasets that inform studies of ancient civilizations, languages, texts, and artifacts. By aggregating diverse data sources, the resource helps users efficiently discover relevant open data for comparative analysis, cross-referencing, and further interpretation, enabling more robust scholarship and collaborative research across related disciplines.

This repository provides specialized Open Data Kit (ODK) forms tailored for archaeological data collection in the field. By leveraging the ODK platform, these forms enable researchers to capture detailed information about sites, artifacts, layers, and observations on mobile devices, even offline. Data is then synced or exported for additional analysis or archiving. The project streamlines workflows and enhances data quality through predefined prompts and standardized entry fields, making it an ideal tool for archaeologists who need reliable, flexible, and efficient means to gather structured data in remote or challenging field environments.

description: This script helps you clean up your digital photograph database by automatically updating the Exif.Image.Artist metadata tag for each file, based on user input and camera models. By doing so, you can keep track of who took each photo, especially if you have a diverse collection from multiple contributors. Whether you are a hobbyist, professional, or curator, this tool simplifies the process of attributing photographs to the correct creator, making your archive more organized and accurate.

TRiDaS is a universal data exchange standard designed to help dendrochronologists store, convert, and interpret tree-ring data. The project includes a core specification plus libraries and tools for reading, writing, and converting data files used by researchers in fields such as archaeology, ecology, and climate science. By standardizing data formats, TRiDaS aims to facilitate more efficient sharing, cross-comparison, and long-term preservation of dendrochronological research datasets.

Expotime is a Python script designed to examine how the exposure time of your photographs correlates with the time of day they were captured. By analyzing image EXIF data, it can identify patterns in lighting conditions, shutter speed adjustments, and camera settings, providing valuable insight for photographers looking to improve their technique. The tool automates data collection, aggregates the results, and presents them in an accessible, easy-to-interpret format.

Zoolog is an R package designed to streamline the manipulation of log-ratios (log size indices) derived from measurements of zooarchaeological material. By providing functions for data cleaning, transformation, and analysis, Zoolog aids in creating standardized, comparable datasets for morphological and metric studies of animal remains. Researchers can easily integrate Zoolog into their archaeological workflows to better interpret past human-animal interactions. The package’s user-friendly interface and methodological guidance facilitate rigorous data-driven approaches in zooarchaeology, ensuring reproducible results and enhanced research outcomes.

Iconr is an R package delivering a comprehensive suite of formal methods to explore and analyze archaeological iconographic datasets, including rock-art, pottery decoration, and stelae. By leveraging network and spatial analysis, it helps researchers compare motifs, measure morphological similarities, and interpret patterns within cultural contexts. This toolkit fosters a deeper understanding of visual elements across distinct archaeological sites, facilitating robust quantitative approaches to iconographic research. With user-friendly documentation and examples, it aims to streamline the workflow for analyzing large-scale image-based datasets in historical and archaeological investigations.

Heurist is a user-friendly, web-based data management platform designed for researchers across the humanities, social sciences, and beyond. The system allows users to structure, analyze, and visualize data through a robust interface without requiring specialized programming skills. It supports advanced data modeling, relationship mapping, and customizable reporting, enabling collaborative research projects and data sharing. With a flexible design that scales to various project sizes and needs, Heurist fosters comprehensive, dynamic data exploration and insight generation.

anthropmmd is an R package designed to facilitate morphological analysis using Smith’s Mean Measure of Divergence (MMD). It includes a user-friendly graphical interface, advanced trait selection, and built-in visualization tools for exploring differences among populations. By enabling researchers to effectively standardize data and interpret patterns in morphological variation, anthropmmd supports anthropological and bioarchaeological studies that focus on evolutionary trends or population affinities. Its integration with R ensures a flexible and reproducible workflow for rigorous statistical evaluation.

rdss is an R package designed to implement Murail et al.'s (1999) method for sex estimation in archaeological or historical contexts. By streamlining data input, performing robust analyses, and generating automated visualizations, it helps researchers investigate demographic patterns and human osteobiography with improved accuracy. The package includes built-in functions for data preparation, parameter calibration, and result interpretation, making it an indispensable tool for anthropologists, bioarchaeologists, and forensic scientists.

3D-ORGAN is a generative adversarial network-based approach for partial scans transformation, offering a robust digital reconstruction pipeline for incomplete archaeological objects. By analyzing missing geometric parts in artifacts, the tool employs advanced deep learning methods to restore structural and aesthetic elements, aiding archaeologists in digital restoration tasks. This system can be integrated into research workflows to model, visualize, and interpret cultural heritage objects more accurately, bridging the gap between partial data and comprehensive 3D reconstructions.

description: unstruwwel is an R package for automatically detecting and parsing historical date references from text data, enabling researchers to systematically study historical records. It uses advanced pattern recognition and string processing to identify approximate and partial date references, simplifying the analysis of archives, manuscripts, and textual corpora. The package can handle multiple date formats, including those with uncertain or incomplete data, and outputs normalized date formats to facilitate chronological modeling. By offering specialized functionalities for temporal data extraction, unstruwwel assists scholars in building robust research workflows for historical studies.

MAX is an advanced web-based software platform designed for the comparative analysis of museum databases, enabling researchers to explore and compare large collections of historical or archaeological data across multiple institutions. The platform was developed by an interdisciplinary team from LMU Munich. It provides data ingestion, statistical analysis, and dynamic visualizations to offer deeper insights into object relationships, provenances, or curatorial decisions. By providing flexible tools for import, transformation, and analysis, MAX fosters collaborative research among museums, universities, and academic communities, advancing digital humanities scholarship.

HumanOS is a user-friendly mobile application designed for the streamlined and intuitive recording of human osteological remains from archaeological sites. By guiding researchers through standardized data entry forms, it helps ensure consistent, high-quality documentation of bone features, measurements, and context. The tool also supports metadata linking, morphological categorization, and on-site data validation, resulting in a robust, dynamic dataset. Developed for use by archaeologists, it significantly speeds up field data collection while enhancing the reliability of recorded information.

ArchAIDE is a research-driven software tool designed to streamline the identification and classification of archaeological pottery fragments through advanced digital technologies. Developed by an interdisciplinary team, the platform automates shape recognition, transforms captured images into structured data, and supports robust data analytics. By leveraging machine learning and pattern matching, ArchAIDE enhances the speed and accuracy of pottery identification, enabling archaeologists to focus on interpretation rather than routine tasks. This innovative tool fosters collaborative research, preserves documentation, and helps uncover new insights into ancient material culture.

Archaeo-Term is a multilingual glossary that unifies specialized archaeological terminology from various languages, aiming to improve cross-linguistic communication and reduce ambiguity in archaeological research. By providing standardized definitions, usage guidelines, and relevant references, it eases collaborative work among experts and students across different linguistic backgrounds. This resource fosters better data sharing, broadens global opportunities, and promotes interdisciplinary dialogue within archaeology and the broader humanities.

C14 is an R package that provides streamlined workflows for gathering, calibrating, and analyzing radiocarbon data in archaeology and related fields. It integrates tidy data principles for easier manipulation and interpretation of 14C datasets, enabling researchers to calibrate dates, visualize distributions, and examine temporal patterns. By offering robust functions and user-friendly syntax, the package aims to facilitate reproducible research, bridging advanced statistical methods with practical field applications. C14 fosters best practices in chronological modeling and extends support for interdisciplinary studies.

description: rpaleoclim is an R package that provides streamlined access to open paleoclimate datasets for scientific research, enabling effortless retrieval, manipulation, and visualization of historical climate information. By leveraging robust data structures and R’s ecosystem, it simplifies the exploration of multi-time-scale climate records, facilitating workflows that combine paleoclimate reconstructions with other forms of archaeological or geoscientific analysis. Designed for both efficiency and user-friendliness, rpaleoclim empowers researchers to investigate past environmental conditions and test hypotheses about climate-driven changes.

These data revolve around the distribution of ungulate mammals in the Middle East as documented by Uerpmann (1987). The dataset includes references to archaeological sites, species presence, and other relevant attributes that help researchers track patterns in ancient fauna. By providing a compilation of occurrence records gleaned from published literature, the resource aims to facilitate cross-cultural comparisons and deeper analyses in zooarchaeology, paleobiology, and historical ecology. This curated database helps highlight transformations in animal communities, offering an important reference point for future research.

Baydem is an R package providing Bayesian tools to model and reconstruct past demography from data such as radiocarbon dates. By applying advanced Bayesian inference techniques, it estimates population size changes over time while accounting for uncertainties in the data calibration process. This flexible framework is particularly valuable for archaeology and other historical sciences, as it helps reveal human settlement patterns, cultural shifts, and demographic transitions. Baydem’s modular design and comprehensive documentation facilitate integration into broader research workflows, delivering rigorous, reproducible analyses of spatiotemporal population data.

Allen-relations is an R function that leverages the Allen Algebra to compare indefinite intervals derived from Bayesian calibration. By translating uncertain time spans into formally recognized relationships—such as before, after, or overlapping—it offers a structured approach to analyzing chronological data in archaeology and related fields. Researchers can use it to refine event timelines, test hypotheses, and better interpret incomplete or ambiguous temporal evidence.

oxcAAR is an R package that integrates the chronologically oriented calibration software OxCal with R scripts. This package streamlines the process of calibrating and analyzing radiocarbon dates within R, facilitating efficient workflows for archaeological and historical research. By providing functions that interface directly with OxCal's robust calibration algorithms, oxcAAR enables researchers to seamlessly generate, manipulate, and visualize calibration outputs. With this tool, scholars can automate routine tasks, refine chronological models, and produce reproducible research outcomes in the field of radiocarbon dating and cultural heritage studies.

cTransmission is an R package that provides an Approximate Bayesian Computation framework to analyze cultural transmission from frequency data. It enables researchers to model and compare different cultural evolution scenarios, bridging simulation-based approaches and Bayesian inference. With flexible parameter settings and clear visual outputs, it facilitates robust investigation into how cultural traits emerge, spread, and persist. This tool is particularly suited for exploring cultural dynamics in archaeology and anthropology, making it a valuable resource for investigating the driving forces behind cultural change.

nimbleCarbon extends the NIMBLE framework with specialized utility functions and probability distributions for Bayesian analyses of radiocarbon dates, assisting researchers in investigating shifts in population dynamics or cultural processes over time. By harnessing the changing frequencies of these dates, the package supports the robust modeling of chronological data, enabling more nuanced demographic inferences. nimbleCarbon is particularly suited to archaeologists and paleoecologists who seek to explore or visualize temporal patterns in a flexible, user-friendly environment.

description: skyscapeR is an R package designed for data reduction, visualization, and analysis in skyscape archaeology, archaeoastronomy, and cultural astronomy. This tool helps researchers explore the relationship between celestial phenomena and archaeological sites or cultural artifacts. By providing functions to handle horizon data, star catalogs, and alignment calculations, it facilitates robust analyses of how past societies perceived and utilized the sky. With built-in visualization capabilities, skyscapeR aids in generating insights and fosters interdisciplinary collaborations between archaeology, astronomy, and cultural heritage studies.

fastmaRching is a robust R package that implements the Fast Marching Method (FMM), initially proposed by Sethian (1996), with refinements by Silva and Steele (2012, 2014). It includes a spatial wrapper function that facilitates modeling of dispersal scenarios in geospatial contexts, making it particularly valuable for investigating prehistoric population movements. By combining mathematical efficiency with user-friendly tools, fastmaRching streamlines data analysis and simulation processes for researchers, enabling them to explore complex spatial phenomena and transformations in archaeology, ecology, and beyond.

Archive des Datations Radiocarbones d'Afrique centrale (aDRAC) is a resource that compiles radiocarbon dating results from Central Africa. It archives published data, associated metadata, and references for each date, enabling researchers to explore chronological frameworks across diverse sites. By centralizing this information, aDRAC supports comparative studies and fosters a deeper understanding of regional archaeological and historical timelines. The dataset includes essential contextual details and bibliographic sources, making it a valuable tool for scholars investigating human occupation, environmental changes, and cultural transitions in Central Africa.

Seriation is an R package that provides a comprehensive suite of methods for reordering matrices, dissimilarity matrices, dendrograms, and more. By implementing seriation, sequencing, and ordination techniques, it offers flexible approaches to identify underlying structures within data sets. The package also supports advanced visualizations, including optimally reordered heatmaps, color images, and clustering plots, as well as VAT and iVAT for assessing cluster tendency. Highly extensible, Seriation is widely applicable in fields like archaeology, bioinformatics, and social sciences.

It was originally designed for analyzing archaeological spatiotemporal datasets, but can be applied in diverse research scenarios. By enabling reproducible and flexible visualization, Bleiglas supports dynamic data transformation, facilitating advanced modeling and interpretation of 3D structures in R.

description: NeolithicR is a Shiny web application that allows archaeologists and researchers to discover, filter, and analyze radiocarbon dating samples from multiple reference databases. Built on top of the R package c14bazAAR, it helps users visualize and calibrate archaeologically relevant radiocarbon data. The app's interface is user-friendly, featuring interactive filtering options and dynamic visual outputs for cross-comparing different radiocarbon datasets. By integrating curated data sources and direct calibration functionalities, NeolithicR provides a powerful environment for investigating chronological patterns and drawing meaningful insights in archaeological or prehistoric research.

idaifieldR is an R package designed to seamlessly integrate data from the iDAI.field database, an archaeological information system maintained by the German Archaeological Institute, into the R environment. By providing flexible data retrieval functions, it enables researchers to effortlessly access, transform, and analyze excavation records, metadata, and other relevant information. The package supports iterative data workflows by ensuring that all data from the iDAI.field platform remains transparent, reproducible, and easily shareable in the context of archaeological or historical research. With idaifieldR, scholars benefit from a streamlined connection between field data and advanced statistical or visualization workflows.

iDAI.field is an open source field research documentation system developed by the German Archaeological Institute (DAI). It integrates GIS, photo management, and database functionalities to streamline archaeological workflows, reducing the need for multiple separate systems. Its flexible data model supports both new and legacy excavation data. Because it is open source, third parties can freely adopt and adapt it to their requirements, making it a versatile solution for archaeological field projects.

datplot is a specialized R package that converts date ranges into straightforward 'steps,' facilitating chronological analysis of archaeological or historical data. By standardizing time intervals, users can track changes over time in areas like pottery consumption or other relevant variables. This ensures intuitive visual comparisons and reliable interpretations. The package provides robust functions to process raw data, manage date uncertainties, and format outputs for seamless visualization. Researchers can glean clearer insights from temporal datasets, ultimately improving their capacity to analyze significant shifts in material culture.

Aoristic is an R package designed to address temporal uncertainty in event data, commonly used in criminology and historical research. By calculating aoristic weights for each possible time interval of an event, it helps researchers handle incomplete or ambiguous timestamps in a structured manner, generating more nuanced analyses and visualizations. This approach can be particularly beneficial for analyzing ephemeral or uncertain time frames, such as those frequently encountered in chronological studies. The package simplifies data processing, fosters reproducibility, and supports robust temporal modelling.

Outliner is an R Shiny application that helps users trace the outlines of irregular shapes (images or other visual inputs) to generate coordinate data. By loading an image and drawing around its edges, researchers can capture precise shape information for potential morphological or geometric analysis. While it does not itself provide advanced analysis, Outliner’s exported coordinate data can be used in many downstream processes, such as comparing artifact shapes, performing morphological studies, or visualizing differences between shapes from multiple sources. Outliner requires ImageMagick and can be easily launched via R’s Shiny interface from GitHub.

outlineR is an R package that automatically detects and extracts outline shapes from multiple artifacts in JPEG images, enabling morphological analysis. It facilitates comparative research by providing standardized shape data for subsequent statistical analysis and interpretation. Developed with a focus on archaeological and historical objects, outlineR helps researchers quantify the geometry of artifacts, thereby assisting in classification, documentation, and cross-comparative studies. The tool is also generalizable for other image-based shape extraction tasks, offering flexibility and reproducibility for a wide range of scholarly inquiries.

THANADOS is a digital humanities platform that actively processes, visualizes, and curates archaeological data, especially focusing on burial contexts. With interactive maps, advanced searches, graph interfaces, data export features, and curation of anthropological information, it goes beyond static data hosting. Supported by OpenAtlas databases and referencing established standards like CIDOC CRM, THANADOS offers tools for multi-site management, radiocarbon calibration, and 3D modeling, making it a comprehensive resource for archaeologists seeking robust data analysis and collaboration features.

Swapdata is an actively developed R package that consolidates a variety of archaeological and palaeoenvironmental datasets focusing on Southwest Asia’s prehistory. By offering scripts, tests, and workflows, it facilitates data wrangling, analysis, and automation tasks in archaeological research. This resource enables researchers to integrate, transform, and interpret raw data, advancing insights into the region’s past. The GitHub repository includes documentation, continuous integration workflows, and code examples to guide users.

This repository provides a curated list of all known historical and contemporary radiocarbon laboratory codes that have appeared in published references, offering researchers a centralized resource to identify, cross-reference, or analyze how these laboratory codes are used over time. By collecting these identifiers across multiple publications, it aims to support more accurate data linking, referencing, or quality control in radiocarbon dating and ensures that labs are consistently documented, thus facilitating collaboration and transparency across the field.

This repository provides a comprehensive dataset of radiocarbon measurements and associated metadata for Rapa Nui (Easter Island). It collates historical and ongoing research findings, offering centralized access to chronological information that can support various archaeological and anthropological inquiries. By standardizing data points and referencing key literature, this resource facilitates cross-comparison of dating results and encourages collaborative analysis. Researchers can use these data for reconstructing settlement patterns and refining cultural chronologies.

description: Caddonet is a curated bibliography of peer-reviewed articles focusing on Caddo archaeology from 2000 onward. This repository aims to provide a comprehensive listing of major studies, field reports, and academic analyses on the Caddo peoples, their heritage, and archaeological investigations of their historical sites. By collecting these references in one place, caddonet facilitates quick discovery of research materials, fosters collaboration among scholars, and encourages ongoing study of Caddo history, culture, and archaeological legacies.

Seriation is a set of algorithms, implementations, manuscripts, and test cases for iterative deterministic frequency seriation done by agglomeration. It aims to systematically reorder and group data frequencies for analyzing patterns in archaeological or historical contexts. This approach helps identify chronological sequences and relationships in data by focusing on the distribution of artifacts, events, or occurrences across multiple time segments. Through an iterative process, the method refines the ordering until a coherent and interpretable arrangement emerges.

OpenAtlas is an open source, web-based platform designed to unify and simplify the management, analysis, and visualization of complex archaeological, historical, and geospatial data. Built around established standards such as the CIDOC CRM, it allows researchers to create, link, and interpret datasets, enabling collaborative, dynamic exploration of cultural and historical information. Its features include robust versioning, user-friendly interfaces, and flexible data modeling options.

statuAAR is an R package developed for analyzing skeletal remains by providing methods to estimate human stature from measurements of long bones using well-established anthropological formulas. Intended for archaeologists, forensic anthropologists, and researchers, this tool streamlines the process of data input, formula selection, and computed results, facilitating robust analyses of past populations and aiding in forensic investigations. Users can easily incorporate measurements from diverse contexts, generating reproducible estimates that support cross-cultural comparisons. By integrating validated formulae, statuAAR enhances the accuracy of archaeometric research on human skeletal remains.

postAAR-python is a specialized QGIS plugin designed for archaeological investigations, particularly for analyzing posthole data to detect rectangular structures in excavation sites. Built by the Initiative for Statistical Analysis in Archaeology Kiel, it applies advanced pattern recognition techniques to identify clusters of points indicating building footprints. This open-source tool streamlines the analysis of so-called 'postholes,' enabling researchers to draw meaningful inferences about historical or prehistoric housing layouts. By integrating seamlessly with QGIS, postAAR-python offers a flexible and essential resource for automated data processing and interpretation in archaeological projects.

postAAR is an R-based tool designed to streamline the detection of buildings within extensive sets of postholes in multi-occupational archaeological sites. Drawing inspiration from the now-obsolete Windows software 'posthole' by Irwin Scollar, postAAR employs advanced algorithms to identify spatial patterns indicative of past building structures. By automating data analysis tasks, it saves researchers valuable time and facilitates more accurate interpretations of archaeological stratigraphy, ultimately contributing to more efficient fieldwork and deeper historical insights.

nonekXML is a specialized XML-based exchange data format designed for the NoNeK project (Nordmitteleuropäische Neolithische Keramik), with the aim of facilitating the sharing and comparison of standardized archaeological data related to Neolithic pottery from Northern Middle Europe. By providing a structured syntax and schema for capturing morphological traits, decoration styles, and other pottery attributes, nonekXML enables researchers from different institutions to communicate findings more effectively, ensure more consistent data curation, and ultimately foster collaborative analysis within and beyond the NoNeK community.

lecAAR is an open-source R package that calculates the largest empty circles in a given region of interest to estimate potential archaeological site locations, following the method introduced by Andreas Zimmermann and Karl Peter Wendt (2003). By automating calculations of distances and spatial distributions, it helps researchers identify areas with no known sites and hypothesize about undocumented or undiscovered ones, facilitating deeper exploration in archaeological surveys.

Dimensio is an R package that offers straightforward implementations of Principal Components Analysis (PCA) and Correspondence Analysis (CA) using Singular Value Decomposition (SVD). In addition to providing methods to compute, extract, summarize, and visualize multivariate data, it also includes partial bootstrap validation for robust quantitative insights. With its simple yet flexible interface, Dimensio helps researchers interpret complex datasets by highlighting underlying patterns and relationships.

Folio is an R package that provides easy access to curated datasets related to archaeology and paleontology, intended for teaching and demonstration purposes. The package compiles varied historical and archaeological data resources, enabling educators, researchers, and enthusiastic learners to explore topics such as fossil classification, excavation site analysis, and more. By offering these datasets in a user-friendly format, Folio helps facilitate hands-on instruction in data manipulation, statistical analyses, and visualization within R. This resource fosters practical skills development for aspiring professionals in archaeology, paleontology, and historical science.

yada (Yet Another Demographic Analysis) is an R package designed to facilitate robust demographic analyses. It provides specialized tools for modeling population structure and estimating demographic parameters, with applications in areas such as forensic anthropology, archaeology, and related fields. By integrating advanced statistical methods, yada can manage and interpret complex datasets, offering functionalities for data transformation, visualization, and inference. Researchers can leverage its user-friendly interface and comprehensive documentation to streamline workflows, enabling more accurate and efficient demographic research.

paleocar is an R package that performs spatio-temporal paleoclimate reconstructions by analyzing tree-ring data with the CAR method, pioneered by Zuber and Strimmer. It yields robust climatic predictions, assisting researchers in archaeology, ecology, and related fields. By modeling historical climate fluctuations, it enhances our understanding of past environments, enabling more informed interpretations of cultural and natural phenomena.

description: tdar is an R package that facilitates robust, programmatic interaction with the Digital Archaeological Record (tDAR), enabling researchers to query, retrieve, and manipulate archaeological datasets hosted by Digital Antiquity. By offering streamlined data access, it helps users seamlessly integrate tDAR resources into their workflows for analyses and visualization. This fosters reproducible research, as it allows dynamic retrieval of metadata, site records, and cultural resource data from tDAR's extensive holdings within the R environment.

This curated resource provides an extensive compilation of academic publications, articles, and other materials on agent-based modelling (ABM) within archaeology. It is designed to help researchers, students, and enthusiasts explore a variety of methodological approaches, theoretical perspectives, and empirical case studies. This bibliography covers diverse topics including simulation frameworks, computational methods, and analyses of past societies. By aggregating valuable references in one place, it aims to foster dialogue, collaboration, and further innovation in the application of ABM techniques to archaeological research.

ABM tutorials is a comprehensive collection of educational materials that introduce archaeologists to the principles, techniques, and practical implementations of agent-based modeling. Through step-by-step instruction, these tutorials demonstrate how to set up, run, and analyze simulations, enabling researchers to explore various hypothetical scenarios and better understand past human behaviors. Ideal for beginners, this resource covers the fundamentals of ABM, includes sample code, and provides best practices for integrating these methods into archaeological analyses, thereby enhancing the study of complex social and environmental interactions.

SPARTAAS is an open-source R package designed to assist archaeologists and researchers in performing statistical pattern recognition and advanced dating techniques. Focusing on the analysis of archaeological artefacts assemblages, the tool integrates algorithms for classification, clustering, and timeline estimation. By combining robust statistical methods with domain-specific knowledge, SPARTAAS streamlines the interpretation of complex data sets and enhances the accuracy of cultural and chronological insights, making it an indispensable resource for scientific data-driven archaeology.

Bonify is a specialized software platform that allows researchers to upload, explore, and manipulate 3D models of faunal remains for archaeological and zoological studies. By providing advanced visualization, annotation, and measurement tools, it helps scientists interpret morphological features, track changes over time, and document findings. Bonify streamlines comparative analysis, fostering collaboration and sharing among researchers worldwide.

Alligator is a web-based application designed to facilitate the conversion of chronological data, including dating information, into relative time intervals encoded as RDF, supporting a wide array of archaeological and historical datasets. By providing a user-friendly interface and leveraging standard semantic web technologies, Alligator streamlines the process of linking temporal data with relevant contextual metadata. Researchers can utilize its features to build precise chronological frameworks, ensuring interoperability among different datasets and enabling advanced analyses of cultural, temporal, and geographic data in the realm of archaeological and historical sciences.

geoCore is a QGIS plugin developed by T-Systems On-Site Services GmbH that helps geologists, engineers, and researchers visualize petrographic drilling data. By automating the process of reading, processing, and plotting geological drill logs, geoCore transforms raw input data into comprehensive diagrams, enabling users to better interpret subsurface materials, patterns, and structures. Its integrated workflow ensures a user-friendly experience for exploring complex geospatial data, supporting situational analysis, resource planning, and decision-making in fields like geology, mining, and environmental studies.

Archive of content created during the annual Day of Archaeology from 2011 to 2017, showcasing the diverse range of work carried out by archaeologists, volunteers, and specialists around the world. Maintained by the Archaeology Data Service, this collection includes blog posts, photographs, and reflections that highlight excavation techniques, research findings, and public outreach initiatives. By preserving these personal perspectives, the archive provides a valuable historical snapshot of archaeological practice, offering educators, students, and enthusiasts a resource for learning, collaboration, and inspiration within the field.

Tachy2GIS is a specialized software solution for archaeologists and historians that merges tachymeter readings with manual vertex creation in a GIS environment, facilitating the generation of detailed, accurate spatial data. By capturing measurement data directly from tachymetric devices, it streamlines the process of mapping and documenting sites, ensuring high precision while reducing manual overhead. Researchers can further refine or modify shapes on demand, enabling flexible workflows for data collection and processing. This robust functionality makes Tachy2GIS an invaluable tool for both fieldwork and subsequent analysis or interpretation.

Bioanth is an R package that offers curated datasets and minimal helper functions to facilitate biological and forensic anthropology research. The package includes well-known cranial measurements, osteometric data, and optional transformations for data frames, enabling scientists interested in morphological studies to quickly access and prepare relevant data in R. While primarily focused on data availability, researchers can leverage additional R libraries for advanced statistical analysis, making this package a convenient starting point for investigating anthropological or forensic questions.

Roman-amphitheaters is a comprehensive digital repository that provides open-access geospatial and historical data on Roman amphitheaters. This resource includes location coordinates, architectural details, and chronological information drawn from multiple scholarly sources. Researchers and enthusiasts can use the included Jupyter notebooks to manipulate, visualize, or analyze the dataset, enabling deeper insights into the historical significance and distribution of these monumental structures. By combining a robust dataset with sample data processing tools, Roman-amphitheaters offers a valuable starting point for archaeological and historical science investigations focused on engineering, cultural, and spatial aspects of amphitheaters.

This repository provides a comprehensive dataset of anthropogenic radiocarbon dates from archaeological contexts in the Caribbean region. It consolidates published records from diverse field reports and academic studies, offering a vital resource for researchers investigating human activity, migration patterns, and cultural developments across the islands. By centralizing these chronological data, the project aims to facilitate comparative analyses and foster interdisciplinary collaboration in Caribbean archaeology. This data-based resource does not appear to provide specialized code or software for data processing, focusing instead on data compilation and accessibility.

Crop_Origins_Phylo is a data repository that compiles the origins and phylogenetic relationships of various crop plants. This resource includes a robust Crop Origins Database, which documents cultivation antiquity, geographic distributions, and morphological descriptors for a wide variety of food-producing species. Paired with the Phylo Food tree, which offers a time-calibrated phylogenetic structure, the repository provides a valuable reference for researchers exploring plant domestication patterns, evolutionary biology, and historical agro-ecological frameworks. Updated versions ensure continuous improvement, fostering deeper insights for comparative analyses and interdisciplinary investigations in botany, archaeology, and beyond.

The dataset includes metadata on sample context, lab identification, and site details, making it an indispensable resource for cross-referencing data across various projects. Researchers can utilize it to investigate cultural transitions, population dynamics, and environmental events. By providing a thorough record of dated material, NERD fosters more comprehensive analyses of the region's past.

description: ElementSourcing is an R-based script that assists archaeologists in analyzing and interpreting elemental composition data from artifacts. By leveraging data from X-ray fluorescence or other spectrometry methods, this tool systematically collects, cleans, and analyzes chemical signals. Researchers can then infer an artifact’s origins, production methods, and authenticity through robust statistical analysis. This streamlined workflow fosters reproducibility and promotes interdisciplinary collaboration, making ElementSourcing a valuable resource for advanced archaeological research on provenance and artifact composition.

elemSource is an R package that provides a streamlined workflow for analyzing element composition data, particularly from X-Ray Fluorescence (XRF) scans. With robust functions for data import, cleaning, and transformation, it allows researchers to effectively compare and interpret elemental distributions. By integrating with specialized libraries, the package offers a flexible environment for reproducible research, making it simpler to document and share results, especially for archaeological or material sciences investigations.

CeramicApportioning is an R-based script designed for chronological modeling of ceramic assemblages. It accounts for site occupation periods, ceramic production intervals, and distribution popularity curves to refine the understanding of artifact deposition over time. By integrating these variables, the tool aids archaeologists in accurately partitioning ceramic data into coherent temporal slices, providing deeper insights into changes in settlement patterns and material culture. This approach enhances interpretations of site occupation sequences, trade networks, and cultural dynamics, offering a valuable methodological framework for researchers working with ceramic datasets.

Kairos is an R package designed for archaeologists and historians to conduct advanced chronological analyses on count data. By implementing robust statistical and computational methods, Kairos facilitates the exploration of temporal patterns, enabling researchers to interpret changes in artifacts, practices, or populations over time with a high degree of precision. The package offers multiple modeling approaches, data visualization options, and interactive tools, making it suitable for projects that require flexible customization. This software thus streamlines complex workflows, from data preparation to final interpretation, thereby enhancing the reproducibility and transparency of archaeological chronologies.

Nexus is an R package designed for the chemical composition-based sourcing of archaeological and geological materials. Through integration of various analytical methods, including XRF and neutron activation analysis, the package facilitates robust data processing workflows for comparing elemental composition. It supports tasks such as data cleaning, normalizing, and statistical modeling to aid in identifying material provenance. Nexus thus enables archaeologists and researchers to interpret and visualize their chemical datasets efficiently, offering comprehensive documentation and reproducible methods for collaborative research.

TransmissionBias is a specialized R package that provides an agent-based model (ABM) to study the processes of cultural transmission in anthropological or historical contexts. It focuses on content, frequency, and demonstrator biases, allowing researchers to simulate how these biases shape the spread and evolution of cultural traits. By offering flexible parameter settings and customizable modeling approaches, TransmissionBias helps in understanding the underlying mechanisms behind cultural dissemination and adaptation across different groups, time periods, or geographical regions. This tool provides valuable insights into cultural processes relevant to archaeology, anthropology, and related fields.

This repository contains a GNU Octave function that assists researchers in estimating the biological sex of skeletal remains. By analyzing morphological measurements from ancient or modern bone samples, the function applies specialized anthropological formulas to yield statistically grounded sex estimations. Through these features, it contributes to bioarchaeological, forensic, and zooarchaeological research, enabling more accurate interpretations of skeletal data across different contexts. The tool’s flexible and open-source nature fosters collaborative advancements in anthropology and related disciplines, addressing a fundamental need in analyzing osteological collections.

long-bone-diaphyseal-CSG-Toolkit is a specialized GNU Octave package that facilitates advanced cross-sectional geometry analyses for diaphyseal long bones. By integrating user-friendly scripts with robust computational methods, it enables researchers to measure, visualize, and interpret morphological traits in anthropological or archaeological contexts. This flexible tool supports parametric modifications, batch processing, and customizable data outputs, making it ideal for comparative studies on bone adaptation, mechanical stress, or evolutionary changes. Through its data-driven approach, the toolkit fosters reproducibility and collaboration, further enhancing insights into long-bone structural properties.

This repository provides a set of MATLAB scripts designed for osteometric sorting of human remains, enabling researchers to systematically measure, categorize, and compare osteological data. By integrating robust morphological metrics and statistical approaches, it simplifies the process of sorting fragmented or co-mingled specimens. Researchers can adapt or extend these scripts for forensic, bioarchaeological, and broader anthropological investigations, facilitating reproducible and methodical analyses.

Skullanalyzer is a specialized script for the morphological analysis of cranial features, designed to support research in biological anthropology and zooarchaeology. By automating the extraction and measurement of cranial landmarks, this tool facilitates the comparative study of skeletal remains across various species or populations. Built in MATLAB, it helps researchers efficiently process high-resolution data, visualize morphological differences, and uncover significant variations related to evolutionary or cultural factors. Its integrated workflow streamlines data pipeline steps, from initial data capture to final analysis, making it suitable for advanced academic and field studies.

cranial-sex-estimation-code is a data analysis tool for assessing a novel sex estimation approach using morphological data derived from skullanalyzer. By applying MATLAB-based statistical and computational techniques, it processes raw skeletal measurements to discern trait distributions that aid in determining sex from cranial morphology. The workflow includes data input, transformation, and results visualization, ensuring reproducible and systematic evaluations. This script provides anthropologists with a streamlined, transparent method to refine analytical methods, expand sample sizes, and compare standardized sex estimation outcomes in bioarchaeological or forensic contexts.

This repository provides a suite of GNU Octave functions designed for analyzing biodistance data using non-metric traits from human skeletal remains, bridging morphological, anthropological, and statistical approaches. By providing a flexible scripting environment, it facilitates the measurement of genealogical relationships or population interactions through data processing, statistical tests, and visualization. Researchers in biological anthropology, zooarchaeology, or related fields can incorporate these methods into their workflows to glean deeper insights into populations' genetic and environmental influences. This tool actively assists in analyzing, modeling, and interpreting morphological trait distributions.

By guiding users through hands-on exercises and detailed explanations, it fosters a deeper understanding of how to apply quantitative approaches to archaeological inquiries.

pta_data provides researchers and the general public with a freely accessible repository of historical Christian texts from the Patristic era, offering a central location for collecting, preserving, and sharing these critical materials. description: Arothron is an R-based suite of methods for Virtual Anthropology, offering tools to construct virtual endocasts, align disarticulated 3D models, and convert file formats for morphological analyses. By automating the processes of image-based shape reconstruction and comparison, Arothron streamlines both data collection and analysis, making it simpler to visualize, quantify, and extract morphological features from skeletal remains or other anatomical specimens. As such, it's well-suited for zooarchaeological or paleoanthropological studies investigating shape variation, functional morphology, or evolutionary patterns across diverse taxa.

CSGR (Cross-Sectional Geometry Tool) is an R-based software that automates the extraction of long bone cross-sections from volumetric data, generating cortical thickness maps and biomechanically pertinent cross-sectional geometric properties. Developed by anthropologists, CSGR helps researchers explore morphological variations in skeletal remains by measuring critical indicators of bone strength, shape, and adaptation. These insights illuminate how skeletal forms change across different populations and time periods, bridging morphological evidence with anthropological and archaeological interpretations. The tool’s robust integration with established practices makes it an asset in osteological and related research.

These scripts implement kriging, a geostatistical methodology for interpolating spatial data. Designed for ethnographic and archaeological research, they help map and predict data trends across geographic locations, enabling researchers to derive meaningful insights from incomplete datasets. Features include robust interpolation, handling of large data sets, and straightforward integration with R-based workflows. Archaeologists use these scripts to better understand site distributions, resource availability, and cultural phenomena. By generating accurate predictions and visualizations, these codes facilitate deeper spatial analysis and hypothesis testing in historical and anthropological studies.

Geostat is a suite of R scripts aimed at facilitating geostatistical analysis within ethnographic and archaeological research contexts. By integrating robust spatial data handling and advanced statistical methods, Geostat enables researchers to model, visualize, and interpret spatial distributions of cultural or historical artifacts, ecological sites, and more. The tool streamlines data processing workflows, promotes reproducible analysis, and fosters collaboration among scholars seeking to uncover meaningful spatial patterns.

spDates is an R package that provides robust methods for analyzing spatiotemporal patterns in radiocarbon data. It incorporates calibration, modeling, and simulation features to investigate how radiocarbon-dated events vary across geographic locations. By leveraging spatial statistics and advanced computational tools, spDates facilitates a deeper understanding of temporal dynamics in archaeological or paleontological research contexts, enabling researchers to identify and interpret spatial gradients in radiocarbon dates. This package can also integrate with mapping platforms to visualize results, making it an essential resource for scholars seeking to contextualize their chronological datasets regionally or globally.

rxpand is an R package that provides a curated dataset of 2,762 radiocarbon dates from 1,023 archaeological sites in tropical South America, focusing on the material cultures related to the spread of polyculture agroforestry and ceramics. Xronos.R is an R-based platform that centralizes and processes chronological data from archaeological contexts worldwide, with a special focus on radiocarbon and dendrochronological records. It offers tools for data calibration, cleaning, and statistical analysis, enabling researchers to compare, interpret, and refine chronological frameworks across multiple sites and time periods. IsoArcH is an open-access, community-driven platform that standardizes and curates isotopic data from across the globe, focusing primarily on bioarchaeology, forensic sciences, and environmental sciences. Researchers can store and share their datasets, benefiting from best practices in data organization and referencing, including DOIs. The platform fosters collaboration and knowledge exchange by encouraging discussions about data harmonization and common ways to explore, interpret, and compare isotopic measurements. Though IsoArcH provides a user-friendly interface for data discovery, it primarily serves as a centralized repository rather than offering fully integrated analysis or modeling tools.

Bridging the Gap ENCODE Database is an online resource that defines and consolidates key digital competencies essential for graduate students and professionals engaged in the preservation, study, and interpretation of written cultural heritage. By outlining shared standards and best practices, it aims to foster skill development in digital tools, research techniques, and data management. The platform offers structured guidance and frameworks to prepare users for evolving demands in heritage-related academic and professional contexts.

A curated dataset of 4,010 radiocarbon dates from Italy spanning from the Late Mesolithic to Late Antiquity. It compiles and standardizes previously published 14C data from a range of archaeological contexts, supporting chronological analyses, calibration, and archaeometric research. By offering a comprehensive framework for cross-referencing dates, AIDA aids in exploring cultural, environmental, and population dynamics over long timescales, and encourages reuse in advanced calibration tools.

The IntCal data package provides the IntCal20 suite of radiocarbon calibration curves, alongside previous IntCal curves and postbomb curves. By applying these curves, researchers can convert radiocarbon measurements into calendar years, improving the accuracy of chronological assessments in archaeology, geology, and related fields. The package integrates data from multiple sources to model atmospheric carbon fluctuations over millennia, thereby enabling rigorous calibration for diverse datasets. These resources also facilitate advanced statistical analyses, simulations, and comparisons across temporal and spatial contexts, making it a vital tool for archaeological and paleoenvironmental research.

SCEM is an R package that uses the Splitting-Coalescence-Estimation Method to model birth seasonality in studies of herd animals, assisting researchers in analyzing how seasonal patterns shape animal population structures. The tool integrates stable isotope analysis and zooarchaeological data to simulate and assess fluctuations in birth adherence. SCEM supports data-driven insights for archaeological or ecological research contexts, enabling robust, reproducible results for investigating herd investment strategies and breeding management practices. It is maintained on GitHub and available through CRAN for easy installation.

MarblePlan is a software tool that allows archaeologists, historians, and other researchers to load, visualize, and analyze fragments of ancient or historic marble floor plans. By facilitating the digital reconstruction of partial or damaged site diagrams, it supports deeper insight into building techniques, materials, and layout design processes. Users can upload scanned fragments, manipulate them in three dimensions, and annotate their specifications for further study and comparison. This platform—designed with user-friendliness in mind—empowers collaborative research, fosters data-driven interpretations, and helps preserve valuable archaeological documentation.

Uniform Probability Density Analysis is an R package for analyzing the spatial and temporal distribution of archaeological data. By using advanced statistical methods, it allows researchers to identify clusters, uniformities, or anomalies in data sets, facilitating better understanding of settlement patterns, cultural changes, and artifact distributions. This flexible tool is particularly valuable for comparing multiple data sets, testing hypotheses, and providing insights into the underlying processes shaping archaeological and anthropological phenomena.

Charcoalhearths is a Python-based tool that processes geospatial data, specifically GeoTIFFs, to identify and map historic charcoal hearth sites. By applying shape recognition and remote sensing techniques, it aids researchers in archaeology or environmental history to detect and analyze these features across landscapes, shedding light on past industrial activities. This automated approach helps streamline data analysis and fosters deeper insights into charcoal production patterns.

p3k14c is a comprehensive global repository of archaeological radiocarbon date data compiled from multiple publications and regional databases. By collating thousands of radiocarbon measurements, it aims to enhance cross-cultural and temporal analyses, refine chronological frameworks, and further our understanding of human prehistory. Researchers can integrate this data with their own analyses or reference it in broader interdisciplinary research. The dataset is structured to support comparative studies, meta-analyses, and advanced archaeological research.

p3k14c-data-scrubbing is a Python-based tool that cleans and processes radiocarbon data from a global archaeological dataset. This software helps archaeologists remove duplicates, standardize date formats, and weed out erroneous or incomplete records. By providing robust data sanitization workflows, it ensures that radiocarbon analyses remain consistent and accurate, facilitating advanced tasks like calibration and chronological modeling. It's especially valuable for large-scale studies requiring cohesive data interpretation across multiple sites, helping researchers push the boundaries of our understanding of the human past.

IsoDataVis is a practical resource and toolkit that helps researchers produce clear and informative stable isotope charts while highlighting best practices in data visualization. This repository offers step-by-step examples, tips on color choices, labeling conventions, and suggested software solutions. Additionally, it provides guidance on effectively presenting stable isotopic data in a variety of contexts, including archaeological and ecological studies. By providing both conceptual guidelines and practical tools, IsoDataVis supports a consistent and visually appealing approach to stable isotope data representation.

Isotope-Visualisation is a collection of scripts and tools aimed at facilitating the analysis and graphical display of stable isotope data in archaeological and environmental research. By enabling users to dynamically transform raw isotope measurements into informative charts, diagrams, and comparative visualizations, it aids in interpreting results across various contexts, such as diet reconstruction or environmental baselines. The repository also includes documentation, tutorials, and sample datasets that guide researchers in effectively customizing and deploying the tool for their specific research questions. This resource thus helps streamline the isotopic analysis workflow.

This repository provides a practical demonstration of applying social network analysis techniques using R to archaeological datasets. By exploring relationships among artifacts, sites, or other relevant entities, it facilitates a deeper understanding of historical or cultural connections. The included scripts guide users through data import, transformation, and visualization steps, making it easier to interpret and present results. Ideal for learners or researchers new to SNA, it exemplifies how computational methods can shed light on complex social structures within archaeological contexts.

ABMA (Agent-Based Modeling for Archaeology) is a computational framework that leverages agent-based simulations to investigate archaeological phenomena. By modeling interactions among virtual agents representing individuals or communities, researchers can examine complex socio-environmental processes such as settlement patterns, resource competition, and cultural diffusion. This repository provides tools, examples, and documentation to facilitate customizing and running simulations rooted in archaeological data, allowing users to test hypotheses, explore scenarios, or teach computational methods in interdisciplinary courses.

Rock Art Transfer Learning is a Python-based software tool designed to help researchers in archaeology analyze and date rock art images. By harnessing the power of machine learning and advanced image processing, it automatically identifies stylistic and morphological patterns, enabling a deeper understanding of chronological sequences. This tool facilitates robust cross-dataset comparisons, streamlining complex analysis tasks, and supports reproducible research. Through transfer learning techniques, it adapts pre-trained models to efficiently handle large volumes of data, ultimately improving the accuracy and speed of rock art classification.

UThwigl is an R-based package that performs closed- and open-system uranium-thorium (U–Th) dating for geological and archaeological samples. By processing isotope ratios and decay constants, it helps researchers accurately determine sample ages and infer historical timelines. The tool can handle complex scenarios, such as multi-phase diagenesis and partial open-system behavior, providing robust estimates of sample chronologies. With built-in data processing capabilities, UThwigl streamlines data input, offers customizable modeling options, and exports detailed results, making it indispensable for scientists studying sedimentary records, cultural artifacts, and environmental changes.

description: Coffee is an R package employing advanced Bayesian methods to maintain the chronological ordering of radiocarbon and other date-based information. By integrating calibration routines, uncertain intervals, and distribution-based data, it helps researchers refine age models, test varied chronological hypotheses, and produce robust time-range estimates. Specifically designed for archaeology, historical sciences, and related fields, Coffee seamlessly processes new or existing datasets, ensuring an accurate representation of temporal sequences while providing reproducible, transparent analysis for thorough and reliable results.

rbacon is an R package that applies Bayesian statistics to reconstruct accumulation histories in sedimentary deposits, such as lake, marine, or peat cores. It divides each core into multiple vertical sections and approximates sediment accumulation rates based on prior distributions, allowing users to incorporate known constraints and calibrate radiocarbon dates. By iteratively testing plausible sedimentation scenarios, rbacon helps researchers produce robust age-depth models essential for understanding environmental, archaeological, and historical contexts. Its flexible framework supports interdisciplinary studies and cross-referencing with other chronological methods.

This R-based simulation tool, called 'pollencount,' helps students and researchers to explore and identify different pollen grains under the microscope. By providing interactive features, it aims to provide an educational environment where users can gain familiarity with the morphological characteristics of pollen from various plant species. The tool’s features guide novices in understanding shape, size, and distinctive attributes of pollen, helping them develop analytical skills crucial for palaeobotanical and environmental research. Through practice modules and visual aids, pollencount streamlines the learning process and fosters better pollen identification techniques.

OpenLidarToolbox is a QGIS plugin that streamlines the transformation of airborne LiDAR data from raw point clouds into detailed visualizations. By automating key steps in data import, classification, and feature extraction, this tool supports a wide range of research applications, including archaeology, geology, and environmental studies. Its user-friendly interface and robust capabilities make LiDAR analysis accessible to researchers of all experience levels.

pXRF is an R package specifically designed to facilitate data processing, analysis, and visualization of portable X-Ray Fluorescence (pXRF) measurements. Developed by Martin Hinz, it offers robust functionalities for cleaning, calibrating, and interpreting geochemical data, enabling researchers to glean insights into archaeological, geological, and related fields. Through streamlined workflows, it helps integrate pXRF results into broader research contexts for more comprehensive, reproducible outcomes.

NearPresence is an R package that implements a technique called Near Presence Cluster Analysis, designed to detect and measure clustering patterns in presence-absence data within irregularly distributed areal units. By systematically examining the distances between observed points and their neighbors, the package helps researchers identify significant spatial structures and interpret how phenomena disperse across a region. This method is particularly useful for studies focusing on population distribution, disease mapping, ecological surveys, and other spatially dependent phenomena, all requiring accurate cluster detection.

DACORD (Computer-Assisted Drawing of Archaeological Pottery) is an R-based script that streamlines the digital reconstruction and shape analysis of ceramic vessels from archaeological excavations. By processing photographic or scanned images, the tool automates the identification of morphological features, enabling researchers to quickly generate accurate vessel profiles for further study or publication. With its user-friendly interface and adaptable workflows, DACORD reduces manual tracing and measurement errors, facilitating consistent analysis across multiple sites and contexts. Through these capabilities, it significantly enhances efficiency in archaeological pottery research.

RACORD is an R-based software that offers automated shape classification workflows for archaeological pottery fragments. By applying morphological analysis methods, the tool assists researchers in identifying and categorizing ceramic sherds from excavation contexts. It aims to facilitate in-depth study of shape variation, enabling archaeologists to glean insights into production techniques, cultural practices, and chronological frameworks. These results can enhance documentation, research collaboration, and comparative studies across multiple excavation sites.

dplR is an R package that enables comprehensive tree-ring data analysis, including reading, visualizing, and processing ring-width measurements as well as detrending methods for chronology construction and crossdating. It provides valuable computational workflows for studying growth patterns and climate relationships, with broad applications in fields such as dendrochronology, paleoclimatology, ecology, and historical research of wooden artefacts. The package offers robust functionality for standardizing data, generating chronologies, and quality control.

xDateR is an interactive Shiny app aimed at streamlining the crossdating process for dendrochronological analyses. By comparing ring patterns from different tree-ring samples, xDateR helps identify matching ring boundaries, ensuring accurate chronological alignment. This tool can produce visual feedback on ring alignment, highlight potential mismatches, and facilitate iterative refinement of the dating process. Developed primarily for researchers in environmental sciences, archaeology, and historical climate reconstruction, xDateR offers user-friendly controls for robust data interpretation. The app's open-source environment fosters collaboration and replicable research practices, elevating the reliability of dendrochronological studies.

Kidstats is a Shiny application that enables researchers and practitioners in biological anthropology and related fields to estimate subadult ages based on dental and skeletal development, as well as diaphyseal metrics. By leveraging pre-optimized mixed cumulative probit models, this tool provides more accurate, data-driven age range estimates. Kidstats facilitates deeper insights into subadult growth patterns, aiding in bioarchaeological, forensic, and clinical contexts by enriching research with robust, reproducible analysis.

Through user-friendly visualization tools and data processing workflows, it enables researchers and practitioners to observe, measure, and compare patterns of skeletal damage, thereby improving casework insights. This R-based tool aims to streamline investigative procedures and support the systematic study of trauma events in both contemporary and historical skeletal remains.

By automatically identifying and classifying archaeological entities in textual data, it offers researchers a structured way to analyze excavation reports, scholarly works, and digitized archives. The tool transforms unstructured text into a rich dataset, enabling deeper analyses, cross-referencing of entities, and improved data management processes. Implemented in Python, Archaeo-CRF is adaptable and integrates easily into various academic workflows, making it a versatile resource for professionals in archaeology and historical sciences.

Chronup is an open-source R package designed to simulate, model, and analyze chronological uncertainties in historical, archaeological, or any other time-driven datasets. By integrating advanced probabilistic methods, it helps researchers better understand the implications of uncertain or incomplete data, ultimately refining their timeline estimations. Chronup's flexible functionalities and streamlined workflows facilitate robust exploration, allowing for reproducible and transparent chronological analyses.

Recmod is an R package that provides robust methods for analyzing and modeling Radiocarbon-dated Event Count (REC) data. By focusing on the complexities inherent to chronological modeling, this tool helps researchers refine their estimations of temporal parameters, producing more reliable insights into historical patterns and events. With built-in functionality for parameter estimation and model calibration, recmod largely benefits archaeologists and historians working with chronologically structured data sets. The package further supports flexible data handling and advanced statistical techniques, enhancing reproducibility and interpretability in research contexts.

Timeperiod2daterange is a Python script designed to parse references to temporal ranges commonly encountered in historical and archaeological data. This helps researchers unify chronological data in large datasets, making it simpler to correlate, visualize, and interpret results across multiple sources. Built to integrate seamlessly with existing workflows, Timeperiod2daterange fosters improved data transparency and reproducibility in digital humanities scholarship.

fellingDateR is an R package that helps dendrochronologists and other researchers estimate and combine felling dates from historical tree-ring series, even with incomplete sapwood data. The tool’s streamlined workflow automates data preprocessing, modeling, and result interpretation, making it indispensable in archaeological and historical studies.
